H0.text: Heat being added to oxygen is what the equation 2H₂ + O₂ → 2H₂O shows.

H1.text: Helium mixing with oxygen is what the equation 2H₂ + O₂ → 2H₂O shows.

H2.text: Heat combining with oxygen is shown by the equation 2H₂ + O₂ → 2H₂O.

H3.text: Hydrogen and oxygen combining is shown by the equation 2H₂ + O₂ → 2H₂O.

A4.text: The stoichiometric combustion of methane in air is CH4methane + 2 O2 + 7.54 N2⟶ CO2 + 2 H2O + 7.54 N2.

A5.text: Hydrogen can be used in fuel cells to produce electricity, or burned to generate heat.

A6.text: When hydrogen is consumed in fuel cells, the only emission at the point of use is water vapor.
